posts.cooked:
Hello! Programming student here. First time posting on Chief Delphi so apologies if my post doesn’t follow conventions.

My team is struggling with pathplanner and encountering the following problem:

The robot can translate and rotate correctly with no PID configured in pathplanner’s AutoBuilder, i.e. just feedforward

The robot can translate and hold its rotation (correct rotational error) with PID enabled if pathplanner does not command a rotation

The robot will spin out of control and translate extremely rapidly if PID is enabled and pathplanner commands a rotation

The robot will drive in reverse/speeds are inverted

This is the path that works correctly.

This is the path that drives incorrectly.

Here is how our auto builder is being configured:

The robot’s estimated pose from GetEstimatedPose() is being calculated from both the odometry and vision systems combined, and works properly/gives accurate values in teleop. GetRobotRelativeSpeeds() also reports correct values. However, calling DriveRobotRelative() from pathplanner will drive in reverse unless the chassis speeds are inverted. I’m wondering if this has anything to do with the issue.

Here’s a link to the full code for all relevant files in case it helps:

There are more than three files. show original

Thanks in advance!

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Can you share all of your code? The easiest way is to upload it to a public GitHub repository and share a link.

My guess is that your drive code isn’t right, it’s not PathPlanner. Look at this Coordinate System document and see if it looks like what you have.

My guess is that your gyro is not rotating the correct direction. When the robot rotates counter-clockwise (left) the value from the gyro should get larger .

It’s not clear from your post, but you also mentioned something about driving in reverse. If that’s the case, you probably are driving your robot “backwards” in teleop, this is a common mistake. Joysticks and XBox controllers produce a negative Y value when you push the stick upward. The X and Y translation, as well as the rotation need to be inverted to drive correctly.

link_counts.title: Coordinate System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Coordinate System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Sure, here’s the link:

Contribute to FIRSTTeam3189/Robot2024 development by creating an account on GitHub.

The value from the gyroscope does get larger as the robot rotates counterclockwise. Also, in my opinion, the robot should not be able to correct rotational error during a straight path if the gyro is inverted.

The joystick values are being inverted, in Commands/Drive.cpp here:

The only strange thing I’ve seen is that the autonomous is using m_pigeon.GetRotation2d() directly, so the value isn’t normalized to (-Pi, Pi). However, I don’t understand why this would immediately cause a path to fail for rotations less than pi radians.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

My guess is that your gyro is not rotating the correct direction. When the robot rotates counter-clockwise (left) the value from the gyro should get larger .

This would also be my first guess and most common problem

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I see the code you copied in your GetDesiredRotationalVelocity() method, but it’s opposite in execute() :

Assuming you’re using an “Always blue origin” scheme, you need be inverting your joystick translation when you’re blue and not inverting when you’re red.

You always want to invert your joystick rotation. Rotation is always counter-clockwise positive, regardless of alliance color.

I understand, and we are using blue alliance origin always. However. we are using an alternate control scheme where the angle of the rotation joystick corresponds to the angle of the robot directly, rather than the robot’s rotational velocity.

The joysticks are inverted because forward on blue alliance is 0 degrees but forward on red is 180. You can see the rotation is always inverted when it is returned from GetDesiredRotationalVelocity() .

This is likely unrelated to the actual issue as the drive command is only used in teleop; all the autonomous functions are the ones used by AutoBuilder in SwerveDrive.cpp . Drive.cpp works correctly, so any discrepancies would be for SwerveDrive.cpp .

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Popcorn:

This is likely unrelated to the actual issue as the drive command is only used in teleop; all the autonomous functions are the ones used by AutoBuilder in SwerveDrive.cpp . Drive.cpp works correctly, so any discrepancies would be for SwerveDrive.cpp .

I always start with the teleop controls when all I have access to is the code, because it’s impossible to determine the proper motor inversions without access to the robot. The fact that you’re driving the robot “backwards” in teleop is an indication that your motor inverts (and probably your offsets) are incorrect. PathPlanner is going to give you a positive X value when it wants you to drive toward the red alliance wall. If positive X values drive your robot toward the blue alliance wall, you might think PathPlanner is wrong because your teleop code is “working”, but it’s actually your drivetrain that is wrong. Your teleop is just working around it to get the behavior you want.

Since you have physical access to your robot, I suggest you start at the beginning and verify you are using the correct coordinate system.

Using Tuner X, blink every one of your devices and make sure the ID matches what you have in your SwerveModuleConstants . I think this is probably right, but it’s worth taking a minute to verify.

Using Tuner X, graph the current position of each CANCoder, one at a time, and rotate it counter-clockwise / left (when viewed from the top). Confirm the position gets larger . If it gets smaller, flip your CANCoder inversion.

Using Tuner X, graph the current position of each of your steer motors, one at a time, and rotate it counter-clockwise / left (when viewed from the top). Confirm the position gets larger . If it gets smaller, flip your motor inversion.

Align all of your wheels so they’re pointed roughly forward (check that the bezel gears are all pointed the way you expect.) Using Tuner X, confirm that the current position reports roughly zero, not 0.5. If it’s 0.5 (or another value), your offsets are wrong. Don’t skip this step, it’s very common that the offsets are off by 0.5 rotations when teams have the behavior you’re seeing.

Make sure the wheels are still pointed forward. Using Tuner X, graph the current position of each of your drive motors, one at a time, and spin it in the forward direction. Confirm the position gets larger . If it gets smaller, flip your motor inversion.

If any of the inversions were wrong, you’ll need to adjust the relevant code to set the correct output. For example, if the steer was wrong, you’ll need to adjust the rotation from your joysticks. If the drive motor was wrong, you’ll need to adjust your translation from your joysticks.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Popcorn:

The joysticks are inverted because forward on blue alliance is 0 degrees but forward on red is 180.

Positive X will move the robot toward the red alliance wall.

Joystick inputs are negative when you push forward.

If you’re standing in a blue alliance driver station and looking toward the red alliance wall, you want to push forward on the stick to drive toward the red alliance wall.

Pushing forward on the stick produces a negative value on the joystick’s Y axis. You want to drive the robot in the positive X direction on the field.

This means when you’re blue, you need to invert the joystick translation controls. When you are red, you do not. Now, look at your code in periodic() , it’s backwards.

Sorry, I was looking at the code in GetDesiredRotationalVelocity where the inversions do match the NWU axes. I see now that it is the wrong way in Execute() .

I might not have access to the robot tonight, but will check those steps and the gyroscope tonight if I do; I suspect there is something wrong along the way since we switched which side of the robot is “forward” after we initially did similar setup steps.

I’m not quite sure still if our behavior, where it drives a non-rotating path fine, will be fixed by just the inversions but I’ll update the thread once I find out. Thanks for all the help!

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Make sure you also verify your gyro rotation. If it’s backwards, it might drive a straight path fine, if it’s within tolerance and doesn’t need correction.

If the gyro is backwards, it would rotate out of control because the error would get larger when it’s supposed to get smaller.
